attributes.title: Character Influence on Reality Status Judgements

q1.value: Influence of Characters on Children's Reality Status Judgements (Part 2)

q3.value: Previous research (e.g. Shtulman & Carey, 2007), has demonstrated a clear developmental pattern for the understanding of impossible and improbable statements when these statements are told through a story by an experimenter. Children do not just hear information about impossible and improbable things from people, they also experience these statements in books, TV, and movies from familiar and unfamiliar cartoon characters. Previous research (e.g. Li, Boguszewski, & Lillard, 2015) with popular characters has demonstrated that children may have difficulty differentiating real and fantasy situations within a children’s TV show. As a followup to our original study will measure children's improbable and impossible statements from a real person vs pretend person.

q4.value: Overall we predict, in the real person condition, children will be more likely to say the statements can happen than children in the pretend person condition. Older children will be more influenced by the informant's reality status and thus be more likely to show a larger gap between improbable and impossible statements. Younger children will be less strongly influenced by the informant's reality status and show a smaller gap between improbable and impossible statements.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We have a mixed design with 2 between-subjects factors and 1 within-subjects factor. Between-subjects factor 1 is age with 3 levels (4, 6, 8) and between-subjects factor 2 is condition with 2 levels (real person and pretend person). The one within-subjects factor is item type with 2 levels (improbable, and impossible).

q9.value: Within each age group and gender, children are randomized to one of the two conditions and one of the four orders.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited using a lab database of local families who are interested in research and at local pre-schools and elementary schools. Subjects receive a small prize for participation. Parents must report that their child speaks English. In addition children who incorrectly respond to the check question at the end of the informant's introduction and children who incorrectly respond to the second check question at the end of the experiment will be excluded.

q13.value: There will be 48 participants in each age group. Within each age group, 24 children will be randomly assigned to each conditions.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect a medium effect size of .25 at the standard .05 alpha error probability. This resulted in a suggested a total participant number of 144.

question.value: We manipulate the source of the information that the children receive. Sources include a person described as either real or pretend.

The single outcome variable will be belief in the statements. We will measure this with children indicated "yes" or "no" to the statement being possible, and children will be asked a confidence question if they are "a little sure" or "very sure" of their answer. The scale for the child's belief in a statement will range from 1-4 (1 being not possible and very sure, 2 being not possible and a little sure, 3 being possible and a little sure, and 4 being possible and very sure).
We will take the mean belief in statements for the impossible and improbable items.
We will use a 3 (age: 4, 6, 8) x 2 (condition: real person, pretend person) x 2 (item type: improbable, impossible) Mixed ANOVA to analyze our results.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the post hoc test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. The post-hoc Bonferroni correction will adjust for multiple comparisons.

q22.value: If the child cannot identify the informant's reality status correctly they will be excluded from analysis.

q23.value: If a subject does not complete any of the the questions, that subject will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value: We end the study with a question asking if the informant is real or pretend. If children responds incorrectly, we will look at any differences between these children and the children who responded correctly. Also, we will look at any difference between children who incorrectly answered the informants reality status check after the introduction compared to children who answered this check correctly.

attributes.title: Attentional correlates of third-party punishment and compensation
attributes.description: It has been widely established that people often act against their immediate self-interest to promote norm compliance. One strategy to enforce compliance when norms of fairness and justice have been broken consists in spending resources to punish offenders; compensating victims is an alternative strategy used to re-establish fairness. In this work, we aim at investigating the attentional correlates of preference for third-party punishment and compensation.

q1.value: Attentional correlates of third-party punishment and compensation: how changes to the graphical representation of payoff influence choices

q3.value: People often act against their self-interest to promote norm compliance. Spending resources to punish offenders or to compensate victims are two alternative strategies to enforce compliance when norms are broken. Here, we investigate how attentional processes predict a preference for punishment and compensation. We will employ the Third-Party Justice Game (Civai et al, 2019), where two players share a sum of money until one (offender) steals from the other (victim); participants, who play as witnesses, must decide whether to do nothing or spend their money to either punish the offender or to compensate the victim. From a set of previous studies we have run, we expect that the amount of attention directed towards the offender, compared to the victim, will positively predict punishment. Moreover, we expect that the way in which payoffs are represented influences attention and, consequently, choice. Hence, in one condition, payoffs are being represented as piles of coins: when the offender steals money, their payoff increases by one pile, making the representation of offender’s payoff more visually salient. In another condition, the payoffs are being represented as digits, and no difference in visual saliency is assumed. If this is the case, the idea that bottom-up implicit attentional processes influence complex choices would be supported (Milosavljevic et al, 2011; Parnamets et al., 2015).

q4.value:
We hypothesise that: 
i) punishment and compensation (likelihood of choice and amount spent) will increase with the increase of the level of injustice (coins stolen by the offender). From previous studies, we predict a large effect size (e.g., partial eta-squared of 0.63 for percentage of punish/compensate, and of 0.5 for amount spent, from Civai et al, 2019). 
ii) The difference between the amount of attention (percentage of dwell time) directed towards the offender and the amount of attention directed towards the victim will differ between conditions: when the representation of the offender's payoff is visually more salient (coins condition), the difference in dwell time will be larger compared to when the payoffs are represented as digits (digits condition). Based on our previous experiments, the predicted effect is large (Cohen's d = 0.85 from an independent sample t-test)
iii) The difference between the amount of attention (percentage of dwell time) directed towards the offender and the amount of attention directed towards the victim will positively predict punishment (and negatively predict compensation). Based on our previous experiments, we expect a medium to large effect size (R-squared = 0.21 from regression analysis). We expect to find the same trend when analysing the amount.  
iv) Following from ii) and iii), the condition will also predict the likelihood of punishment: participants will be more likely to punish in the coins condition, when the representation of the offender's payoff is more salient. Based on our previous experiments where we varied the payoff representation between experiments, we expect a medium effect size (Cohen's d = 0.53 from an independent sample t-test). We expect to find the same trend when analysing the amount.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: Since this is a within-participant design, all participants are administered all conditions.

question.value:
This is a within-participant design. In one condition (coins), the payoff of the players (offender, or player A; victim, or player B) is represented as piles of coins; in a second condition (digits), the payoff of the players is represented as digits. Each condition has 64 trials, which vary in the level of injustice: the offender can take 0 (fair), 25, 50, 75 or 100 coins from the victim. For each condition, there are 8 trials for each level of injustice, except for the fair condition (0 coins taken), which has 32 trials: this was done in order to present half fair and half unfair trials (Civai et al, 2019). The presentation of the offender's (player A) and the victim's (player B) payoff on either side of the screen (left or right) is counterbalanced: the offender's payoff is presented on the right (or left) 4 times per level of injustice, per condition. All trials are randomised. 
Uploaded in this section: 
- the materials in detail, i.e., the Third-Party Justice Game (Civai et al, 2019) and the eye-tracking measurements; 
- the instructions to participants
- the source file for the stimuli

q9.value: Items across the two conditions (coins vs digits) and justice levels (from 0 to 100) are randomly presented to the participant through the randomisation function built into Experiment Builder, the EyeLink 1000 software for stimulus presentation (S-R Research, Canada).

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: At the time of this preregistration, the data are still being collected. The data from one pilot participant (excluded from the analysis) were checked to ensure that all the variables were collected and the data correctly saved. No further analysis was performed on the pilot data. The subsequent data (included in the analysis) have not yet been opened and/or checked in any way.

question.value:
Participant are greeted in the lab and then read the instructions for the Third-Party Justice Game (called The Chip Division Game, in order to conceal the aim of the study). Subsequently, participants place their head on a chin rest, and the eye-tracker calibration and validation process begins; participants then start the actual game, after 6 practice trials are delivered to familiarise with the setting. They are told that the practice trials are made up and are not part of the set from which the final payment is selected. Participants are able to ask for breaks whenever they need to rest their eyes, although they are not allowed to move their head. The task lasts on average 25 minutes.

Participants are either paid a show up fee (£5 Amazon voucher) or given 12 credits (if they are London South Bank Psychology students registered on the Research Participation Scheme system, and if they decide to choose credits over voucher); in addition to this, each participant is also given a £5 Amazon voucher as "task dependent" payment.

To take part in the study, participants must be 18 or older; participants are excluded if the calibration and/or validation of the eye-gaze fails.

q13.value:
The required sample size is N=39. 
We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .95 power to detect an effect size of d=0.54 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

q14.value: The effect size was chosen based on the results obtained in the previous studies: specifically, d=0.54 is the effect size of an independent sample t-test comparing the difference between the percentage of punishing and compensating choices in our two previous studies (coins vs digits, between-participant design). This was the smallest effect size amongst our effects of interests (see hypotheses), and also the most interesting effect. Given that this analysis assumes complete independence between the measures (between-participant design), it is more conservative when estimating sample size from effect size.

question.value:
We manipulate: 
- the level of injustice, i.e., the amount of chips that the offender (player A) can take from the victim (player B). Five levels of injustice are considered: 0, 25, 50, 75, 100 chips. 
- the way of representing the players payoffs, either coins or digits

We measure: 
- the percentage of dwell time on the offender's and on the victim's payoff, obtained from the Experiment Builder (EyeLink 1000) software. 
- participants' choice (punish, compensate or leave)
- the amount participants choose to spend to punish and to compensate
- the reaction times in relation to the choice to punish, compensate or leave (reaction times for selecting the amount to spend will not be considered since they are not informative)
The difference between the percentage of dwell time on the offender's and on the victim's payoff is calculated by subtracting the dwell time on the victim from the dwell time on the offender.

Since this is a repeated measure design, we are going to use mixed models in order to account for the random effect of participants. 

To test our hypotheses, we will use: 

- a linear mixed model (lmer function in lme4 R package (Bates et al, 2015)) to test whether the condition (coins vs digits) predicts the difference between the percentage of dwell time on the offender's and the victim's payoffs.

- two generalised linear mixed models (glmer function in lme4 R package (Bates et al, 2015)) to test whether i) the level of injustice (amount of coins stolen by the offender), ii) the difference between the percentage of dwell time on the offender's and the victim's payoffs and iii) the condition (coins vs digits) predict the likelihood to punish (model one) and the likelihood to compensate (model two) for each trial. 

- two linear mixed models to test whether i) the level of injustice (amount of coins stolen by the offender), ii) the difference between the percentage of dwell time on the offender's minus the victim's payoffs and iii) the condition (coins vs digits) predict the amount spent to punish (model one) and to compensate (model two) for each trial.

q20.value: The condition (coins vs digits) will be dummy coded as 1 and 2

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the t-test and the mixed models suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q23.value: If a participant misses (i.e., does not respond to) more than 20% of the trials (13), then that participant will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value: Two linear mixed models will be run to test for the effects of injustice level, the percentage of dwell time on the offender's minus victim's payoffs and the effect of the condition (coins vs digits) on the reaction times to punish (model 1) and compensate (model 2).

q25.value:
Disclosure of related work: 
As briefly mentioned in the "study information" section, a set of studies was previously run employing similar variables. Nevertheless, the effect of interest (coins vs digits representation of the payoff) was not tested as a within-participant effect: in the previous set of studies, one experiment presented the payoffs as coins, and another experiment presented the payoffs as digits. Other two experiments aimed to investigate a different attentional manipulation were also run, but for both of them the payoffs were represented as digits. 
Here, we want to investigate whether the effect of representation (coins vs digits) we observe between experiments can be replicated within participants. 

References: 

Bates, D., Maechler, M., Bolker, B., Walker, S., Christensen, R. H. B., Singmann, H., ... & Bolker, M. B. (2015). Package ‘lme4’. Convergence, 12(1), 2.

Civai, C., Huijsmans, I., & Sanfey, A. G. (2019). Neurocognitive mechanisms of reactions to second-and third-party justice violations. Scientific reports, 9(1), 1-11.

Milosavljevic, M., Navalpakkam, V., Koch, C., & Rangel, A. (2012). Relative visual saliency differences induce sizable bias in consumer choice. Journal of Consumer Psychology, 22(1), 67-74.

Pärnamets, P., Johansson, P., Hall, L., Balkenius, C., Spivey, M. J., & Richardson, D. C. (2015). Biasing moral decisions by exploiting the dynamics of eye gaze. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 112(13), 4170-4175.

- two generalised linear mixed models (glmer function in lme4 R package (Bates et al, 2015)) to test whether i) the level of injustice (amount of coins stolen by the offender), ii) the difference between the percentage of dwell time on the offender's and the victim's payoffs and iii) the condition (coins vs digits) predict the likelihood to punish (model one) and the likelihood to compensate (model two) for each trial. 

- two linear mixed models to test whether i) the level of injustice (amount of coins stolen by the offender), ii) the difference between the percentage of dwell time on the offender's minus the victim's payoffs and iii) the condition (coins vs digits) predict the amount spent to punish (model one) and to compensate (model two) for each trial.

attributes.title: Does scary music mimic biological voice signals of threat?

q1.value: Does scary music mimic biological voice signals of threat?

q2.value: Caitlyn Trevor, Natalia B. Fernandez, Sascha Frühholz

q3.value: Music may communicate emotions by mimicking vocal affective cues (i.e. laughter or sighs). While many examples of this practice exist, it is unknown whether the musical imitations are perceived similarly to the actual vocal cues. We investigate this question by testing whether the same neural networks respond to both a vocal cue (a scream) and its musical imitation (scream-like music) using fMRI.

q4.value: Given our 2x2 stimuli design with the factors scream-likeness (scream-like vs non-scream-like) and sound type (vocal vs musical), we expect that there will be more activation in the aSTG and right IFG for music; the STS and left IFG for voice; and in the AMY, HIP, and anterior insula for scream-like sounds.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: There is no blinding in this study.

question.value: Participants will hear short audio stimuli (800ms) in a 1-back task. The rapid even-related design has 6 runs, 80 trials per run, lasting 1 hour.

q9.value: The sound files will be presented in a pseudorandomized order for each of the 6 runs. Specifically, the pseudorandomization used is random order but with no more than three of the same stimuli type in a row.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: There was a pilot study to match the stimuli for arousal for use in the fMRI study. Three pilot fMRI participants were collected to check data quality before proceeding with the actual experiment.

question.value: We will recruit participants through the University of Zurich online recruitment portal. Our participants should be able to speak English well, be between 18-40 years old, have no hearing damage, have no neurological or psychological diseases, not be musicians, and be right handed or ambidextrous. Participants will be compensated 60 CHF each for their participation. Our criteria for "non-musician" are: i) they do not describe themselves as a musician , ii) they have no scholastic diplomas in music, iii) they haven't been actively playing a musical instrument (~daily) for at least 5 years, and iv) they had no musical training before they were 10 years old.

q13.value: Besides our 3 pilot participants that we ran to ensure that our data quality is optimal, we plan to recruit 35-40 participants for the actual study.

q14.value: We are limited to 60 hours with the fMRI scanner. Each participant takes about 1.5-2 hours. So we are running as many participants as we can during our allotted hours (no more than 40).

q15.value: We will stop collecting data once we have used up our allotted 60 scanning hours, which should result in data from no more than 40 participants.

question.value: Our stimuli have a 2x2 design, including factors scream-likeness (scream-like vs non-scream-like) and sound type (vocal vs musical).
We will measure participant's neural activity in response to each sound file, via fMRI brain imaging data.
Data will be analyzed with t-test contrasts (including scream-like > non-scream-like & music > voice), MVPA, and DCM.

q20.value: The imaging data will be preprocessed using SPM12 in MATLAB.

q22.value: We will look at movement parameters to make sure that all participants were still enough during the study to be included in the analyses. We will also check that their reaction times and task accuracy scores are indicative of them paying attention (reaction time within 2.3 seconds, and at least above 50% accurate).

q23.value: If only some runs are proven to be affected by too much movement, we will exclude only those runs and keep the remaining data (runs unaffected by movement).

q3.value:
The broad goal of this research project is to develop a model of when people will use negation in referential expressions (e.g. saying "not the cat" to refer to a dog when a cat and dog are both present).

In this experiment, we are asking whether having a linguistic convention for either/both of the target and competitor affects the use of negation. We do in two ways. 
(1) manipulating the familiarity of both the target and competitor (e.g. a familiar object like a dog vs. a novel object)
(2) by asking participants to refer to the same object multiple times, which should lead to the establishment of a linguistic convention

We predict that having a linguistic convention for the competitor but not the target leads to negation

q4.value:
(1) When the target is a familiar object, negation should be very close to 0
(2) When the target is a novel object, negation should be more frequent
(3) When the competitor has been referred to on the three previous trials (Switch condition), negation should increase 
(4) the magnitude of this increase should be greater when the novel object is a competitor

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: The experimenter doing the manual check of negation coding will be blinded to the trial type.

question.value: Two experiments using within-subject designs. In experiment 1a, novel/familiar target stimuli will be presented with same type distractors. In experiment 1b, novel targets will have familiar distractors. The study is counterbalanced: there are two blocks within each study and each will be presented first in half of the trials.

q9.value: The particular familiar/novel objects on each trial will be assigned by simple randomization.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will collect data from 50 participants in each of the condition x order combinations (for a total of 200) on Amazon Mechanical Turk. We chose this sample size following Uri Somonsohn's small telescopes suggestion based on successful detection of the predicted interaction (switch x condition) in a pilot sample of 20 participants in each condition.

We will only include Turkers who live in the USA and have an approval rate >95%. Each participant will be paid $0.50 for their participation. The study will remain on the website until we reach 200 participants. 

After data collection, we will exclude participants who do not follow the rules of the study (i.e. random or nonsensical responses). These decisions will be made blind to the condition of the participant

q13.value: This study will have 200 participants. Each participant completes 16 individual trials within the study, so there will be 3,200 data points in the form of messages/utterances.

q14.value: In our pilot data, we found the predicted interaction effect with 40 participants in each condition. Based on the small telescopes principle, we will collect 100 participants in each condition

question.value:
We will manipulate the target and distractor stimuli:
1) novel target and novel distractor
2) familiar target and familiar distractor
3) novel target and familiar distractor
4) familiar target and novel distractor

We will measure the frequency of negation use in each condition.

As a first pass, we will try to automatically detect negation by looking for the word "not" in each response. The output of this coding will be checked by a manual coder who will remove false alarms (e.g. "not sure") and mark as negation anything that was missed (e.g. "non-fruit"). These manual checks will be made blind to the participant's target and condition.

Data will first be pre-processed using analysis/process_raw_data.Rmd, which will output the files for manual coding. The coder will produce a file called data/pre-reg1/manually_code_data.csv which will be loaded in and joined with the rest of the processing pipeline in analysis/pre_reg_e1.Rmd

We will use a logistic mixed-effects model to test for the predicted main effects and interactions (see analysis/pre_reg_e1.Rmd). We will begin with the maximal model and simplify, removing random effects and then main effects, until the model converges and produces no error messages or warnings.

Because the use of negation was so infrequent for known objects in the pilot study as to be nearly 0, a logistic model would not converge (and was not appropriate). For this reason, we will test the predicted interaction only for novel targets while simply predicting that negation for known targets will be very close to 0.

q22.value: After data collection, certain data points will be excluded if they are deemed nonsensical.

q23.value: If a subject does not complete all trials within the experiment, that subject will not be included in the analysis.

attributes.title: eMovit - A mobile application to stimulate the development and engagement in new positive behaviors: A prospective iPhone-based feasibility study using ResearchKit.
attributes.description: eMovit is an iPhone application which facilitates the development and engagement in positive behaviours ranking from physical activity to social or creative engagements. The application is based on the principles of Behavioural Activation. The project is targeted at the general population to test the feasibility, ie. willingness of users, of recruitment and data collection through the means of mobile applications, like eMovit. If the results of this study are positive, it would open new possibilities for research in the emerging world of mobile and web-based interventions.

q1.value: eMovit - A mobile application to stimulate the development and engagement in new positive behaviors: A study protocol for a prospective iPhone-based feasibility study using ResearchKit

q2.value: Leah Bührmann, Heleen Riper, Annet Kleiboer, Tom Van Daele, Nele De Witte, Alina Rinn, Dirk Lehr

q3.value:
In 2015, Apple launched an open-source software framework, called ResearchKit (http://researchkit.org). ResearchKit is designed for medical and health research, facilitating research by providing templates for developing apps and gathering data from study participants using these iPhone apps. Smartphone applications have several advantages over conventional pen and paper methods. They can, for example, remove geographic barriers, allowing for the frequent assessment of participants in real-life settings. This should result in more extensive data, which are also likely of better quality. Smartphone applications may also facilitate study recruitment and reach people who are underrepresented or hard to reach in conventional research.  As such, ResearchKit provides powerful means for tracking and studying the behavior and wellbeing of individuals who engage with medical and health apps.  
To date, numerous ResearchKit apps have been developed addressing medical topics such as Parkinson’s disease (1) or asthma (2). However, study results have only been published for few ResearchKit app-based studies so far. Regarding user and retention rates of the ResearchKit app-based studies, results demonstrate that initial download rates of these apps are often high (e.g. Bot et al. achieving 48.104 app downloads (1)). Unfortunately, the number of users consenting to participate in the research study typically drops drastically, with consent percentages ranging from 14.0% to 57.6% (1–4). The number of active study participants regularly completing assessments was typically even lower, ranging from 9.3% to 11.2% across studies (1,4,5). All of the aforementioned studies have utilised ResearchKit apps on medical topics. Thus, the user and retention rates of ResearchKit apps in the mental health field are still limited.  
eMovit is an app that was built using Apple’s ResearchKit. The aim of the app is to help users to develop new and positive behaviours according to the principles of behavioural activation (BA). The app stimulates behaviours by letting users schedule positive activities and by reminding them on the corresponding day and time. Users can rate their behaviours accordingly, and earn badges and trophies for carrying out these new and positive behaviours. The main aim of this study is, however, not to evaluate the behavioural activation intervention itself, but to investigate the feasibility of the eMovit ResearchKit app to prospectively recruit participants and collect data for research purposes.

Research Questions

1)	Investigate how a mental health app with a broad focus can be disseminated across the general population. 
2)	Investigate the feasibility of iPhone-based recruitment, consent procedures, and data collection for research purposes.
3)	Explore user enrolment, engagement and retention patterns, as well as demographic characteristics of study participants.
4)	Explore the impact of app usage on mood, happiness, and well-being of the study participants. 
5)	Investigate user satisfaction with the app.

q4.value:
1)	We assume that dissemination strategies will be differ in effectiveness across settings, population groups, and countries. We hypothesise that the most effective dissemination strategy will be social media channels as social media is a frequently used medium in our modern world. Disseminating eMovit via social media channels by highlighting the benefits of the app for the user will motivate users to enroll and engage with the app. 
2)	Mobile-based recruitment of research participant, consent procedures, and data collection promises to ease the burden for potential participants to partake in research. Users who experience the eMovit application as a useful tool for improving their behaviors are likely to contribute in further facilitating the research around online interventions for mental wellbeing. 
3)	Female individuals are more prone to engage in mental health related activities, especially via the internet. 
4)	Mood, happiness, and well-being increase with continues use of the eMovit app.
5)	Not applicable.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Observational study focusing on usage data.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: Data has not yet been collected.

question.value:
The data collection takes place online via the Apple ResearchKit and is therefore location independent. The app is released in Apple’s App Stores in Germany, The Netherlands, and Belgium. In parallel to the app release, eMovit will be disseminated via several online portals, following three distinct strategies: 1) an eMovit profile will be created on social media platforms, i.e. Twitter. The profile will contain important information about the content and purpose of the app, example pictures, a link to download the app, and a continuously updated news feature. 2) Organizations (e.g. VU Amsterdam, other universities) with profiles on social media (such as Facebook, LinkedIn, Twitter) will be contacted and requested to advertise the eMovit social media profile (e.g. retweet, post in profile). Key contacts working in and around the eMovit project as well as interested individuals will be contacted to rise the attention on eMovit (i.e., networking). 3) eMovit advertisement will be disseminated across different websites. A general advertisement including a short text, download link, and a picture (e.g., logo) will be created, as well as advertisements focusing on specific target groups depending on the websites which are willing to advertise the app (e.g., focus on students via university websites). Potential websites include websites focusing on lifestyle, positive psychology, or e-health applications.
Additional strategies to advertise eMovit and recruit participants are: to publish short articles or announcements in lifestyle magazines (focus on health, sport, diet, etc.), to feature the app in blogs and vlogs (personal or business), to feature the app in emails such as organisational mail lists or link in email signatures, and to create a mobile app landing page. Dissemination will take place in local languages.

q13.value: The main aim of the study is to test the feasibility of app-based recruitment and data collection. Therefore, we aim at including as many participants as possible and do not set a lower or upper limit for our sample size.

question.value: This study is of observational nature without a control group.

App analytics will automatically be collected including impressions, product page views, installations, sessions, active devices, and deletions. User satisfaction of eMovit will be assessed by a 5-star app rating. Participants demographics that will be collected are age, gender, country of origin, employment status, and whether the participant is a twin/triplet. 
Mood will be assessed with one question asking participants for their current mood using an answer slider scale ranging from 1 to 10. Happiness will be assessed with one question asking participants how happy they feel at the moment using an answer slider scale ranging from 1 to 10. Symptoms of depression will be assessed with the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-8 (6)). The questionnaire consists of eight items tapping in the core symptoms of depression over the past two weeks.
Not applicable.
Descriptive analyses will be conducted to explore usage data. Frequencies of usage, participation in research, as well as length of usage will be investigated.

q22.value: All data will be included in the analysis.

q25.value:
This project is a collaboration between VU Amsterdam, The Netherlands, Thomas More University of Applied Sciences, Belgium, and Leuphana University Lüneburg, Germany.

References
1. 	Bot BM, Suver C, Neto EC, Kellen M, Klein A, Bare C, et al. The mPower study, Parkinson disease mobile data collected using ResearchKit. Sci data. 2016;3:160011. 
2. 	Chan Y-FY, Wang P, Rogers L, Tignor N, Zweig M, Hershman SG, et al. The Asthma Mobile Health Study, a large-scale clinical observational study using ResearchKit. Nat Biotechnol. 2017;35(4):354. 
3. 	Deering S, Amdur A, Borelli J, Drobnich D, Headapohl W, Stepnowsky CJ. SleepHealth Mobile App Study: bringing the sleep lab to you. In: Sleep. OXFORD UNIV PRESS INC JOURNALS DEPT, 2001 EVANS RD, CARY, NC 27513 USA; 2017. p. A287–8. 
4. 	Zens M, Woias P, Suedkamp NP, Niemeyer P. “Back on Track”: A Mobile App Observational Study Using Apple’s ResearchKit Framework. JMIR mHealth uHealth. 2017;5(2):e23. 
5. 	McConnell M V, Shcherbina A, Pavlovic A, Homburger JR, Goldfeder RL, Waggot D, et al. Feasibility of obtaining measures of lifestyle from a smartphone app: the MyHeart Counts Cardiovascular Health Study. JAMA Cardiol. 2017;2(1):67–76. 
6. 	Kroenke K, Strine TW, Spitzer RL, Williams JBW, Berry JT, Mokdad AH. The PHQ-8 as a measure of current depression in the general population. J Affect Disord. 2009;114(1–3):163–73.

This project is a collaboration between VU Amsterdam, The Netherlands, Thomas More University of Applied Sciences, Belgium, and Leuphana University Lüneburg, Germany.

References
1. 	Bot BM, Suver C, Neto EC, Kellen M, Klein A, Bare C, et al. The mPower study, Parkinson disease mobile data collected using ResearchKit. Sci data. 2016;3:160011. 
2. 	Chan Y-FY, Wang P, Rogers L, Tignor N, Zweig M, Hershman SG, et al. The Asthma Mobile Health Study, a large-scale clinical observational study using ResearchKit. Nat Biotechnol. 2017;35(4):354. 
3. 	Deering S, Amdur A, Borelli J, Drobnich D, Headapohl W, Stepnowsky CJ. SleepHealth Mobile App Study: bringing the sleep lab to you. In: Sleep. OXFORD UNIV PRESS INC JOURNALS DEPT, 2001 EVANS RD, CARY, NC 27513 USA; 2017. p. A287–8. 
4. 	Zens M, Woias P, Suedkamp NP, Niemeyer P. “Back on Track”: A Mobile App Observational Study Using Apple’s ResearchKit Framework. JMIR mHealth uHealth. 2017;5(2):e23. 
5. 	McConnell M V, Shcherbina A, Pavlovic A, Homburger JR, Goldfeder RL, Waggot D, et al. Feasibility of obtaining measures of lifestyle from a smartphone app: the MyHeart Counts Cardiovascular Health Study. JAMA Cardiol. 2017;2(1):67–76. 
6. 	Kroenke K, Strine TW, Spitzer RL, Williams JBW, Berry JT, Mokdad AH. The PHQ-8 as a measure of current depression in the general population. J Affect Disord. 2009;114(1–3):163–73.
registration_responses.q8.question: Observational study focusing on usage data.
registration_responses.q12.question:
The data collection takes place online via the Apple ResearchKit and is therefore location independent. The app is released in Apple’s App Stores in Germany, The Netherlands, and Belgium. In parallel to the app release, eMovit will be disseminated via several online portals, following three distinct strategies: 1) an eMovit profile will be created on social media platforms, i.e. Twitter. The profile will contain important information about the content and purpose of the app, example pictures, a link to download the app, and a continuously updated news feature. 2) Organizations (e.g. VU Amsterdam, other universities) with profiles on social media (such as Facebook, LinkedIn, Twitter) will be contacted and requested to advertise the eMovit social media profile (e.g. retweet, post in profile). Key contacts working in and around the eMovit project as well as interested individuals will be contacted to rise the attention on eMovit (i.e., networking). 3) eMovit advertisement will be disseminated across different websites. A general advertisement including a short text, download link, and a picture (e.g., logo) will be created, as well as advertisements focusing on specific target groups depending on the websites which are willing to advertise the app (e.g., focus on students via university websites). Potential websites include websites focusing on lifestyle, positive psychology, or e-health applications.
Additional strategies to advertise eMovit and recruit participants are: to publish short articles or announcements in lifestyle magazines (focus on health, sport, diet, etc.), to feature the app in blogs and vlogs (personal or business), to feature the app in emails such as organisational mail lists or link in email signatures, and to create a mobile app landing page. Dissemination will take place in local languages.
registration_responses.q16.question: This study is of observational nature without a control group.
registration_responses.q17.question:
App analytics will automatically be collected including impressions, product page views, installations, sessions, active devices, and deletions. User satisfaction of eMovit will be assessed by a 5-star app rating. Participants demographics that will be collected are age, gender, country of origin, employment status, and whether the participant is a twin/triplet. 
Mood will be assessed with one question asking participants for their current mood using an answer slider scale ranging from 1 to 10. Happiness will be assessed with one question asking participants how happy they feel at the moment using an answer slider scale ranging from 1 to 10. Symptoms of depression will be assessed with the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-8 (6)). The questionnaire consists of eight items tapping in the core symptoms of depression over the past two weeks.
registration_responses.q18.question: Not applicable.
registration_responses.q19.question: Descriptive analyses will be conducted to explore usage data. Frequencies of usage, participation in research, as well as length of usage will be investigated.

attributes.title: Does Proximity to Nazi Concentration Camps Make Germans Intolerant? Modeling Spatial Heterogeneity and Historical Persistence

q1.value: Does Proximity to Nazi Concentration Camps Make Germans Intolerant? Modeling Spatial Heterogeneity and Historical Persistence

q2.value: Thomas Pepinsky, Sara Wallace Goodman, Conrad Ziller

q3.value:
In a recent article in the American Political Science Review entitled “Legacies of the Third Reich: Concentration Camps and Out-group Intolerance,” Jonathan Homola, Miguel M. Pereira, and Margit Tavits (hereafter HPT) argue that Germans who live nearer to former Nazi concentration camps are more likely to display out-group intolerance.

HPT argue that geography shapes political attitudes and beliefs. They hold that Germans who live near Nazi concentration camps are forced to confront the ideology of the Nazi regime, leading to a form of cognitive dissonance that persists today. While the authors control for several relevant individual- and contextual covariates, they do not include controls for regional heterogeneity related to the federal structure of Germany. We argue that taking the federal structure of Germany into account is pertinent for the analysis of spatial or geographic variations in social and political attitudes.

All of our analyses have employed EVS and electoral data because it is publicly available. However, HPT also analyze restricted-access ALLBUS data, arguing that a third independent data source increases the reliability of their results. ALLBUS data also contain information about respondents’ locations at a lower administrative unit, the Gemeinde or municipality, which allows for a more exact mapping of their distance to a closest camp. The same arguments about regional heterogeneity in the EVS data also apply to the ALLBUS data. We propose, therefore, to replicate their analyses and then extend them using the methods outlined below.

q4.value:
The main hypothesis, we test empirically with ALLBUS data is that the main results of the HPTs study (i.e., negative and statistically significant empirical relationships between the predictor “spatial distance to concentration camps” and the outcome variables of outgroup intolerance) no longer hold (i.e., become statistically insignificant, or flip sign) once regional heterogeneity for Länder (German states) is controlled for.

Technically, such an expected change in the original HPT results will be most likely due to a reduction in the effect size as a result of including, for example, Länder fixed effects in the empirical models. As a result, partial correlations between Länder fixed effects and the location of concentration camps as well as between Länder fixed effects and outgroup are accounted for. We expect the size of the negative effect in the HPT study to be pushed toward zero, or even to flip to positive. (This is what we observed when replicating their analysis using EVS data.) A decrease in the magnitude of the point estimate results in an altered ratio between estimate and standard error, which leads to lower t-values. 

We expect this to occur for all three outcome variables tested in the HPT study, namely: intolerance toward foreigners (Hypothesis 1a), intolerance toward Jews (Hypothesis 1b), and intolerance toward Muslims (Hypothesis 1c).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Our study design involves a replication of the HPT study using ALLBUS data with the extension of empirically modeling regional heterogeneity by Länder (German states). Doing so, we adhere to the empirical model setups of the HPT study involving ALLBUS data. Based on these models, we make the following extensions: a) An inclusion of Länder fixed effects (dummy variables minus one as a reference category) in the main models provided in HPT study; b) Employing random effects specifications that involve random effects by Land. We will also conduct Hausman tests to compare among pooled, random effects, and fixed effects specifications.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value:
We replicated the HPT analyses (with the proposed extensions) using existing data from the European Values Study and from the 2017 German federal elections. Extending this existing replication with EVS data by using ALLBUS data is expected to yield similar statistically-insignificant results. 

We did not have access to data necessary to conduct an analysis with ALLBUS data as this can only be done in the Secure Data Center. We applied for and have received permission to conduct this reanalysis. An analysis of this restricted ALLBUS data will be conducted subsequent to the publication of this pre-registration.

question.value: ALLBUS survey data of the 2016 wave we intend to analyze has already been collected. The geo-referenced data necessary to perform the replication and its extension as intended is stored and administered at the GESIS Secure Data Center in Cologne, Germany. We applied access and will analyze the data in this Secure Data Center subsequent to the publication of this pre-registered analysis plan.

q13.value: Since no data collection is involved in our study, we rely on the sample of the ALLBUS 2016 data. HPT report a varying sample size their empirical models are based on (depending on missing data patterns for included variables) with between 2,787 and 3,233 respondents. This also is the sample size our models will be based on.

question.value: No variables were (experimentally) manipulated.

For variables involved, we adhere to the empirical setup provided by the HPT study (with the extension of modeling Länder differences using fixed effects), which means that we use the same variables and steps of scale construction. 

Specifically, the used outcome index variables (i) intolerance toward foreigners, (ii) intolerance toward Jews, and (iii) intolerance toward Muslims are built by using factor scores (first factor of a principal component analysis) of three indicator variables for each index. 

The main predictor variable is the distance between a respondents’ municipality (Gemeinde) and the closest former concentration camp. This measure has been computed by HPT and will not been altered to ensure a correct replication the HPT results and a valid extension based on the original results.

As control variables, we use HPT’s model setup and use corresponding individual-level covariates (i.e., gender, education, being unemployed, living area (degree of urbanity), living in west vs. east Germany, left-right self-placement), as well as interwar covariates (i.e., % Jews (1925), % Unemployed (1933), Population (1925), Nazi party share (1933)) and postwar covariates (i.e., unemployment rate at the Kreis (district) level 2014; share of foreigners at the Kreis (district) level 2014).

The extensions we make in terms of measured variables is to include Länder fixed effects, which are represented by a dummy variable for each Land (minus one Land as category of reference).

In this section we outline the replication and extensions that we plan to conduct using the restricted-access ALLBUS data. In brief, our main replication analyses will recreate Table 1 and Table 2 from the main text of our working paper, replacing the EVS data with the ALLBUS data. These tables will serve as replications and extensions of HPT’s Table 3 (p. 10). 
	
Our proposed Table R1 (R for “replication”)	will run eight regressions on each of three dependent variables, paralleling the structure in Table 1 of the main text. Table A8 shows how this will look; all that is missing are the results.

Our proposed Table R2, in turn, will conduct Hausman tests that compare pooled, random, and fixed effects specifications. Again, all that is missing from Table A9 are the results. 

We also propose to calculate Moran’s I statistic using the methods described in the main text (see p. 12). We will do this both on the ALLBUS main data and on the residuals from Model 3 in Table R1.

Finally, we will compare the interacted fixed effects coefficients by state from Equation (4) in the main text, using Intolerance as the dependent variable from EVS and Intolerance Toward Foreigners as the dependent variable from ALLBUS, using a scatterplot (Figure R1). This will allow us to visually inspect whether or not the unobserved factors that may have explained the EVS results are the same as those that explain the ALLBUS results, or if there are different region-specific factors at play. We plan to attach error bars to each scatterplot. A simulated example using fake data appears as Figure A5.

We also intend to conduct further exploratory analyses, again adopting a multilevel modeling framework to explore heterogeneity by state and closest camp. We similarly anticipate further exploratory analyses that adopt a more explicit spatial econometric framework. But to be clear, we do not intend to pre-register those analyses, which should be understood as data-driven, exploratory exercises. 

The tables and figures can be found in the attached file "PGZ_Tables_Figures.docx"

q21.value: We will use cut-off values for statistical significance as reported in the original study by HPT, which is p < 0.05.
